Abstract This study ai med to present the differences in operating costs (OPEX) and investment costs (CAPEX) of sewage treatment plants (STPs) with and without the need for nutrient removal based on the sanitary effluent discharge limits established by the Brazilian federal and state legislation. A process sizing capable of meeting each standard was carried out with equal flow rates, input quality standards, and kinetic relationships. A minimum sludge age necessary to ensure compliance with the standards was applied for each proc ess. Operational indicators for energy, sludge production, chemical consumption, labor, and cost were compared. In STPs that require ammoniacal nitrogen removal up to 5 mg/L and 20 mg/L, OPEX is 47% and 9% higher than STPs without ammonia removal. Increasi ng the ammonia nitrogen threshold from 5 to 20 mg/L in the discharge standard resulted in a 90.5% and 16.6% reduction in chemical and energy consumption, respectively, and a 25.3% increase in sludge production. Concerning CAPEX, the main difference in inve stment is the size of the equipments and the aeration tank volume for the units with ammonia removal, resulting in 176% larger reactors. Finally, the difference in operating costs and investments for new stations with and without the need for nutrient remo val may make it impossible to meet universal sanitation targets by 2033. Especially in states with more restrictive legislation, which have lower treatment coverage and in which nutrient removal is mandatory.

Introduction Currently, sewage collection in Brazil serves 59.8% of its population, 46.5% of which occurs through a collection and treatment network for collected sewage and the remaining 13.3% corresponds to sewage collected and discharged from irregularly, without treatment, in the receiving body (ANA 2020). In addition, not all sewage collected and treated receives adequate treatment up to the secondary level, whose objective is to reduce the organic load of sewage through i ts oxidation by the action of microorganisms.

Investments in sanitary sewage treatment plants may vary, depending on the environmental legislation of the region or the type of receiving body. This is due to the fact that some Brazilian states or municipali ties have more restrictive legislation when compared to the federal legislation CONAMA n¬∞ 430/2011 (BRASIL, 2011) which does not require the removal of nutrients in sanitary sewage treatment systems. As an example, the state of Rio de Janeiro must remove a mmoniacal nitrogen from sewage treatment plants, according to CONEMA resolution n¬∫ 90/NOP -INEA -45 (RIO DE JANEIRO, 2021). As a result, sewage treatment in the state of Rio de Janeiro demands high investments (CAPEX, capital expenditure) and operating

costs (OPEX, operational expenditure) compared to other states in Brazil. The main objective of this study is to show the difference in CAPEX and OPEX that treatment plants may have due to different environmental legislation and inspections, which can influence the operational routine, through collections, and in the planning of the units. A comparative analysis of CAPEX and OPEX of sewage treatment plants with and without nutrient removal can inform sanitation area professionals of the differences between these scenarios.

Method Case study The study was developed through dimensioning processes of sewage treatment plants to meet different release standards, setting the project input values, such as average flow and raw sanitary sewage quality parameters, such as demand oxygen biochemistry (BO D), chemical oxygen demand (COD), total suspended solids (TSS), total nitrogen (TN), ammonia nitrogen (N-NH4+), oils and greases (O&G), total phosphorus (TP), alkalinity, pH and temperature. The release standards used were the federal legislation CONAMA 43 0/11, considered as scenario A, while the legislation of S√£o Paulo - Decree 8,468/76 (S√ÉO PAULO, 2021) was named as scenario B, while the current legislation of Rio de Janeiro, CONEMA N¬∫ 90 (NOP -INEA -45) is being considered as scenario C and, finally, scen ario D, the repealed legislation of Rio de Janeiro, which refers to NT -202.R10 (RIO DE JANEIRO, 1986) and DZ.215.R -1 (RIO DE JANEIRO, 2007).

Process sizing The process adopted in the study was the activated sludge and for the sizing was considered an average flow of 100 L/s, with the maximum peak flow of 180 L/s, and characteristics of the raw effluent according to intermediate values in the literature (Table 1). For the design, the following factors were taken into account: k inetic relationships (Table 2 ) to calculate biomass growth; definition of sludge age, which represents the average period that the sludge is kept in the system and is directly linked to the aeration tank volume, treatment performance, oxygen demand, and sludge production; Total suspen ded solids in the aeration tank (mixed liquor total suspended solids ‚Äì MLTSS), which means the amount of existing biomass in the aerobic reactor to degrade the organic matter present in the effluent and oxidize the ammoniacal nitrogen to nitrates.

The age of the sludge, or solids retention time (SRT), is a basic parameter for the design and operation of sewage treatment plants, correspondin g to the time that solids remain in the effluent treatment system with suspended growth (Metcalf & Eddy 2016). The use of this parameter in activated sludge projects has a direct correlation with the efficiency of BOD removal and nitrification. Nitrifying bacteria require oxygen and can convert ammonia to nitrite and nitrate (nitrification), resulting in the removal of ammoniacal nitrogen. Nitrifying bacteria demonstrate slow growth compared to heterotrophic (fast -growing) bacteria, which remove organic mat ter. In the sizing project, the age of the sludge will vary in each scenario depending on the release standards required by the standard, especially ammoniacal nitrogen. A minimum sludge age was adopted in the sizing to ensure compliance with the standards in each release strip, and thus demonstrate the different sizing scenarios of the activated sludge system. And also relate the increasing age values of the sludge with the applicable legislation (different levels of restriction), as these factors direct ly impact the CAPEX and OPEX of the unit.

Considerations on design of activated sludge processes Scenario A: CONAMA 43 0/11 The legislation at the federal level only requires the removal of organic matter with a minimum efficiency of 60% or reaching BOD less than 120 mg/L, and because it is federal -scale legislation, it is the least restrictive. With the mandatory removal of organic matter and no requirement to remove ammoniacal nitrogen, the age of the sludge considered for this scenario was 5 days. In a treatment process that does not require nitrification, sewage treatment plants are designed to operate with low sludge a ges, called conventional activated sludge, resulting in lower volume for their construction (METCALF & EDDY, 2016).

Another relevant factor in this scenario is the lower oxygen demand, since complete oxidation of ammonia is not necessary, and oxygen is essential only for the biological degradation of carbonaceous organic matter. According to Metcalf & Eddy (2016), between 0.9 and 1.3g O2/g BOD removed are required for sludge age ranging between 5 and 20 days.

Scenario B: S√£o Paulo - Decree 8468/76 The s tate legislation of the state of S√£o Paulo, Decree 8,468/76, has similar characteristics to the federal legislation and also requires only the removal of organic matter. As it is a state legislation, it must be more restrictive than federal legislation. Th erefore, according to S√£o Paulo (1976), sanitary effluents must be discharged into the receiving body with BOD of up to 60 mg/L or a minimum BOD removal efficiency of 80%. Therefore, a sludge age of 7 days was considered for this scenario, since the mandat ory removal of organic matter is more restrictive than the CONAMA resolution 430/11.
In this scenario, the reactor will have 2 days more compared to scenario A, which will

allow more time for the development of heterotrophic and nitrifying bacteria. As for air demand, despite the greater efficiency of organic matter removal, the same consumption was considered as in scenario A.

Scenario C: Rio de Janeiro (current) - CONEMA N¬∫ 90 / NOP -INEA -45 Scenario C represents the current legislation of the state of Ri o de Janeiro, through CONEMA Resolution No. 90/2021 (NOP -INEA -45), which fully amends DZ 215 -R4 and NT 202 R10 (scenario D) concerning sanitary sewage discharge standards. As a result, starting in 2021, effluent discharges into water bodies in the state of Rio de Janeiro are required to follow the criteria for ammoniacal nitrogen of up to 20 mg/L (by previous legislation, the old standard required was 5 mg/L), organic matter up to 40 mg/L (no changes with the revoked standard) and phosphorus up to 4 mg/L (p arameter added in the update). This update makes Rio de Janeiro's legislation continue to be one of the most restrictive in the country; however, with the change in the required limit for the concentration of ammoniacal nitrogen from 5.0 mg/L to 20.0 mg/L, even with the addition of the phosphorus parameter, which was only required for tertiary level in the old standard, it could accelerate the advance of the universalization of sanitation that the State demands, since the operational costs will decrease.

When comparing this scenario with scenarios A and B, there are more service parameters, such as mandatory nutrient removal, and a greater need for organic matter removal (BOD ‚â§ 40 mg/L). In this case, to reach the parameters established in NOP -INEA -45, a slu dge age of 15 days was adopted in the design, aiming at the removal of organic matter and nitrification to remove ammonia. Thus, the need for oxygen demand is greater, resulting in higher energy consumption, considering that for the complete ammonia oxidat ion to occur, 4.57 g O2/g oxidized N -NH4+ are required (Metcalf & Eddy 2016).

Scenario D: Rio de Janeiro (revoked) - NT-202.R10 and DZ.215.R -1 The old legislation of the state of Rio de Janeiro, adopted by the Instituto Estadual do Ambiente (INEA), throug h NT -202.R -10 (1986) and DZ -942.R -7 (1990) was one of the most restrictive in the country and the world until its update in 2021. This legislation had the same parameters for releasing ammoniacal nitrogen (5.0 mg/L) as CONAMA 357/2005 (resolution revoked i n CONAMA 430/11). In addition to ammonia nitrogen, the parameters such as total non -filterable residues and total nitrogen are also required to be met, compared to the release standards of scenarios A and B. Phosphorus, a mandatory parameter in the current legislation of Rio de Janeiro (scenario C), it was mandatory only for tertiary treatment units, which were defined by releasing the treated effluent into a lentic receiving body. Due to the requirement to remove organic matter and ammoniacal nitrogen (mor e restrictive compared to scenario C), a sludge age of 20 days was adopted, with the objective that the nitrifying bacteria, necessary to transform ammonia into nitrate, have sufficient time to grow.

Conclusion It was observed, by the R$/m¬≥ indicator, that treating sewage in regions with more restrictive legislation, which includes the obligation to remove nutrients, represents a higher cost compared to STPs of flow and raw sewage quality parameters that are the same, but with less restrictive legislation. The higher costs to implement new sewage treatment plants and to treat sewage can make investments in the sector unfeasible, resulting in failure to meet the goals of universal sanitation in 2033. The cost of the R$/m¬≥ indicator for an STP with the removal of up to 5 mg/L of ammoniacal nitrogen is approximately 47% higher than the R$/m¬≥ indicator for an STP without nutrient remo val and

9% higher for plants with the removal of N -NH 4+ up to 20 mg/L. When comparing the operational costs of the stations with only organic matter removal, the values showed similarities, for similar sludge ages. The highest cost, in this case, was the c onsumption of chemical products, which represented 38.7% of the total cost of the most restrictive STP. This cost is mainly due to nitrification, and it is occasionally necessary to add alkalizers such as soda (Na 2CO 3) and geocalcium (Ca(OH) 2) for nitrific ation to occur. Another representative cost in the most restrictive unit for nutrient removal is energy consumption, equivalent to 28.3% of the total cost, due to the number of blowers needed for air injection, in order to oxidize the ammonia.

The update of the state legislation of Rio de Janeiro (NOP INEA 45) provided a savings of 26.2% in the operating costs of the stations that need to carry out the removal of ammonia since the change from 5 mg/L to 20 mg/L in the parameter ammoniacal nitrogen release r esulted in a 90.5% reduction in chemical consumption, a 16.6% reduction in energy consumption and a 25.3% increase in sludge production. In terms of investment, the higher CAPEX required for the construction of sewage treatment systems with nutrient remova l is mainly due to the increase in aerobic reactors, the network of pipes and blowers, diffusers, diffuser meshes, and process control instruments. The volumes of the aeration tanks, when compared to systems without nutrient removal, reached a difference o f 176% in the size of the reactors of the systems with more restrictive removal of nutrients.
